name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Hi Anand,

Thank you for voicing out. But as I said earlier, in order get into the details of ARIMA, Lags, Autocorrelation plot we need to dive deep into time-series modelling. Our assumption is you will learn time-series modelling from other courses and this course teaches you how to apply time-series modelling in python. We need to come up with 3x times of content if we have to dive deep into every algorithm/technique we use in the tools which would be bit too much and is not the scope of this course.

Nevertheless, welcome all your questions if you want to learn. Please do post in discourse. To answer your question -

Autocorrelation plot is used to check how much a value is correlated with respect to its past. Meaning - if you consider stock price data (let’s say IRCTC stock). Let’s say you have 365 day closing price of IRCTC stock in a single column in excel. Now if you create another column ‘lag 1’ where you have 1day lagged price of IRCTC stock. Meaning - for day 2, you have day 1 price, for day 3, you hav day 2 price.

Visually it might seem like this -

IRCTC. IRCTC_Lag1. IRCTC_Lag2
800. NA NA
812 800 NA
811 812 800
828 811 812
…

From the above table you could see lag 1 is previous day value, lag 2 is 2 days before value for every closing price. The first row for lag 1 is NA because there is no previous day value as that is the starting day, and first 2 rows are NA for lag 2 price as there is no 2 previous days values. So we remove those 2 rows from analysis.

Among the remaining values, if you take correlation (irctc, irctc_lag1), correlation (irctc, irctc_lag2) values, these are called autocorrelation values. Basically autocorrelation is correlation of a column with respect to its own past. So we can see autocorrelation for 1,2,3,4,5…n day lags.

Autocorrelation plot visualizes the correlation of present values with respect to its different lag values and thats why it starts from 1 (because correlation of present value with lag 0 is 1, as they are same).

We use this plot to understand which of the lags are significant (lies above the shaded region in the graph) so that we can use those lags as features in our forecasting model or use those lags as moving averages in arima - meaning, if 5 day lag is significant, I can use 5 day moving average in arima.
excerpt:
Hi Anand, 
Thank you for voicing out. But as I said earlier, in order get into the details of ARIMA, Lags, Autocorrelation plot we need to dive deep into time-series modelling. Our assumption is you will learn time-series modelling from other courses and this course teaches you how to apply time-ser…

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Thank you for pointing out that the file is missing in the supplementary materials. I have now added this notebook, please check.
Regarding code - As iterated before, please do not focus on understanding every line of the code. In this code, we use beautiful soup and requests library to do web scraping. The headers = {} is a mandatory syntax which specifies this code could work in which browsers/versions. The params={} has the 2 inputs required (browser to be used, querying term to be used in Google). This is then taken as input and a Google search with the query term is done using the specified browser. Then we look for all img files (.jpg) in the result and save them. The locations/div tags everything are hardcoded by doing inspect element in browser and checking the names of typical google image results.

Thanks,
Mahesh

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked: It is a library that parses text. It looks for html tags and extracts all content in those html tags. For example, a web page titled “Hello World” might be present in html as <h1><b><Hello World</b></h1>. Beautiful soup library has a set of predefined html tags to look for (basically keyword search) and it extracts contents with those tags. In this example, it looks for <h1> and knows it is a html tag and looks for the closure </h1> and extracts all contents between these. You will not get non html content if you use the html parser. It looks only for html content.
excerpt: It is a library that parses text. It looks for html tags and extracts all content in those html tags. For example, a web page titled “Hello World” might be present in html as <h1><b><Hello World</b></h1>. Beautiful soup library has a set of predefined html tags to look for (basically keyword search)…

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Hi Rohit,

Nominatum uses OSM to query details (open street maps). OSM is free and it has very good information extraction for the US and reasonably better in other parts of the world. However it is not that great in handling spell-checks. Your address column need to be having correct address details.

If you think of addresses extracted from proper source, then Nominatim is really good. But if you have address that is open-ended or typed by the user then it is subject to some spell-checks. In those cases Google API is the best. But it is not free and it charges on api as a service. For example, internally in my organization we use google api which can provide much more interesting details.

In those cases, you can also try to use zipcodes. For example search for “600036”, it will return Bacau, Romania - but IIT Madras also has the same zipcode 600036. A coincidence

Nominatum uses OSM to query details (open street maps). OSM is free and it has very good information extraction for the US and reasonably better in other parts of the world. However it is not that great in handling spell-checks. Your address column need to be having correct address detail…

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Q1. In this tutorial we use only geopy because we directly gave example addresses (like IIT Madras, Eiffel Tower, etc.). But when you have addresses in a pandas dataframe then you can either write a for loop or apply function to use this same code for every row of address or directly use geopandas which can use geopy functions from nominatim directly to pandas data frame. You can refer to this example here.

Q2. There are a multitude of potential applications - if you have a zipcode or address column, you can create multiple features using this column like type of place, tourism place or not etc. If you use google maps, they have premium apis which give more details as well like number of schools nearby, number of tall buildings in 5km radius etc. These are very useful features for predictive applications. Another usecase is for recommending correct addresses in apps (like spell-check).

–MB
excerpt: Q1. In this tutorial we use only geopy because we directly gave example addresses (like IIT Madras, Eiffel Tower, etc.). But when you have addresses in a pandas dataframe then you can either write a for loop or apply function to use this same code for every row of address or directly use geopandas w…

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Hey guys, thank you everyone for voicing out your opinions and perspective in a healthy manner. I really appreciate it. I understand it might start to sound like greek and latin for some of you, but we intentionally made the decision to have ML foundations as co-requisite. Because you can learn the theory and try to visit back and connect with the practice (tools) part. Some pointers which could be helpful for all of you having different perspectives (both positive and negative) -

  1. What is the benefit of this course? - passing this course would definitely make you industry ready. And Anand S, who himself is a very accomplished Data Scientist wanted to give the real flavour of how you would be working in Industry (no spoon-feeding, but giving you directions). Most examinations will be open book, open internet or take home.

  2. We will share all the resources (codes, excel, etc.). You can download those supplementary materials from the drive link in course contents page.

  3. There will be youtube live sessions every week and the calendar will be shared soon. Please used these live sessions if you need more help or guidance.

  4. All the instructors in this course are well accomplished data scientists working in industry and most of them also teach in different IITs/IIMs as faculty. So my humble request is to give them all a bit of respect as some of you are bluntly rude.

Definitely this course will be different from other courses because this is going to be an applied course and the idea is to make you know the different quantum of things we could do in data science. I do not think you would be Industry ready unless you get comfortable with this course honestly. Because this is the reality, this is how things are going to be once you interview for or get onboarded as DS.

The materials and case studies are so meticulously curated just for the purpose this course in the past 8 months. They are so valuable and try to explore use the help of live sessions to get your issues sorted out.

Use the Youtube live sessions to the fullest those whoever need more help with this course. We would be more than happy to help. Let’s respect each other and that’s a fair expectation I guess. Thanks!
excerpt: Hey guys, thank you everyone for voicing out your opinions and perspective in a healthy manner. I really appreciate it. I understand it might start to sound like greek and latin for some of you, but we intentionally made the decision to have ML foundations as co-requisite. Because you can learn the …

name: Mahesh Balan U
cooked:
Hi Everyone,

The latest version of the library needs a different user_agent. If many people use same user_agent name then your request would be blocked. So give unique usernames like user_agent=“test123xyz”. It could be anything, it is just a placeholder.

Thanks,
Mahesh
excerpt:
Hi Everyone, 
The latest version of the library needs a different user_agent. If many people use same user_agent name then your request would be blocked. So give unique usernames like user_agent=“test123xyz”. It could be anything, it is just a placeholder. 
Thanks, 
Mahesh
